ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

SAMUT PRAKARN WASTEWATER MANAGEMENT PROJECT 
 
FIFTH SEMIANNUAL  

REPORT 

TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS 

ON 
 
IMPLEMENTATION OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS 
 
OF THE BOARD INSPECTION COMMITTEE 
 
AS ADOPTED ON 25 MARCH 2002 

 

February 2005

I. 

INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND 

 

1. 
On 25 March 2002, the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) met to 
consider the recommendations of the Board Inspection Committee pursuant to the inspection of 
the ADB-funded Samut Prakarn Wastewater Management Project (the Project) in Thailand.1 At 
that meeting, the Board noted the report of the committee and, after deliberation, approved its 
recommendations  as  quoted  in  paragraph  1  of  Board  document  IN.251-02  dated  3  October 
2002.2 This is the fifth semiannual report to the Board, covering the period 26 March 2004 to 25 
September  2004.  Although  the  report  was  scheduled  to  be  submitted  to  the  Board  in  early 
October 2004, it was held back in the expectation of further developments on the Project. 
 
 

II. 

PROJECT STATUS 

2. 
As noted in the fourth semiannual report, as a result of investigations into the Project in 
early 2003 initiated by the Minister for Natural Resources and Environment in the Government, 
the  turnkey  contract  was  declared  null  and  void  on  the  basis  that  there  had  been  contractual 
irregularities. The Executing Agency, the Pollution Control Department (PCD), officially advised 
the turnkey contractor of its decision on 28 February 2003 and ADB on 18 March 2003. Total 
disbursement under the main turnkey contract has remained static since that time at about B20 
billion, out of a total contract value of about B23 billion (87%). PCD announced that it would file 
a civil suit against the turnkey contractor,3 in which it intended to sue for all monies paid to date 
under the contract.  
 
3. 
PCD  did  proceed  with  the  filing  of  a  suit  in  May  2004,  requesting  repayment  of  all 
monies paid under the contract to date, based on its claim that the contract was null and void. 
The  civil  court  rejected  PCD's  claim,  and  recommended  that  it  seek  resolution  of  the  matter 
through the contract’s arbitration provisions. No further progress has been made on this matter.

III. 

COMPENSATION PLAN, MONITORING SYSTEMS, COMMUNITY 
INVOLVEMENT, AND ODOR AND EFFLUENT MANAGEMENT 

7. 
Since the submission of the fourth semiannual report, no further action or progress has 
been made on (i) implementation of the resettlement plan, (ii) implementation of the monitoring 
systems, (iii) community involvement, or (iv) any measures taken that are associated with odor 
and effluent (if any). 
 

IV. 

CONCLUSION  

8. 
After  almost  2  years  of  investigations,  and  following  loan  closure,  the  Project  remains 
incomplete and all project-related activities remain suspended. No further action or progress has 
taken place with respect to the compensation plan, monitoring activities, community involvement 
initiatives,  or  odor  and  effluent  management.  No  further  action  will  be  taken  with  respect  to 
these issues until the contractual dispute between PCD and the turnkey contractor is resolved.
